subject: Economics
title: Daniel Kahneman: The Psychologist Who Won the Economics Nobel
description: A fast breakdown of Daniel Kahneman: The Psychologist Who Won the Economics Nobel for builders.

hook.text: Kahneman never took an economics class. He won the Nobel Prize in Economics in 2002. His field was psychology.

buildup.text: With Amos Tversky, Kahneman showed that humans systematically deviate from rational decision-making in predictable ways.

discovery.text: System 1 (fast, intuitive) and System 2 (slow, deliberate): most economic decisions are made by the fast system.

twist.text: Tversky died in 1996, six years before the Nobel. The prize cannot be awarded posthumously. Their work was inseparable.

climax.text: Kahneman proved that 'homo economicus' â€” the rational agent of economic theory â€” doesn't exist.

punchline.text: The most important economist of our era was never an economist.

quiz.question: What did Kahneman's research prove about economic behavior?
options: Humans systematically deviate from rationality in predictable, bias-driven ways
